{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient presents with severe substernal chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea, which are typical symptoms of a myocardial infarction. The imaging reveals transmural myocardial infarction in the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum. The most likely occluded coronary artery in this case would be the one supplying blood to the posterior 1/3 of the ventricular septum, which is the septal perforators. Therefore, the correct answer is C. Septal perforators.", "answer_choice": "C"}
